questions.question: Fill in the blank with the correct form of the verb: She ___ (read) a book every day.
questions.explanation: The sentence describes a habit, so the Simple Present tense is used. The correct form is 'reads'.

questions.question: Choose the correct tense for the sentence: They ___ (play) football now.
questions.explanation: The word 'now' indicates an action happening at the moment, so Present Continuous tense is used: 'are playing'.

questions.question: Which sentence is in Present Perfect tense?
questions.explanation: Present Perfect tense is formed with 'have/has + past participle', so 'I have eaten' is correct.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: He ___ (study) for two hours.
questions.explanation: The sentence indicates an action that started in the past and is still continuing, so Present Perfect Continuous tense is used: 'has been studying'.

questions.question: What is the correct form of the verb in Simple Past tense: She ___ (go) to the market yesterday.
questions.explanation: Simple Past tense is used for completed actions in the past. The past form of 'go' is 'went'.

questions.question: Choose the correct tense: They ___ (watch) TV when I called.
questions.explanation: The sentence describes an ongoing action in the past when another action happened, so Past Continuous tense is used: 'were watching'.

questions.question: Fill in the blank with Past Perfect tense: I ___ (eat) dinner before the movie started.
questions.explanation: Past Perfect tense is used for actions completed before another past action. The correct form is 'had eaten'.

questions.question: Which sentence is in Past Perfect Continuous tense?
options: He had been working all day.
questions.explanation: Past Perfect Continuous tense is formed with 'had been + verb-ing', so 'He had been working all day' is correct.

questions.question: Fill in the blank with Simple Future tense: She ___ (visit) her grandmother tomorrow.
questions.explanation: Simple Future tense is used for actions that will happen in the future. The correct form is 'will visit'.

questions.question: Choose the correct form: They ___ (play) at 5 PM tomorrow.
questions.explanation: Future Continuous tense is used for actions that will be ongoing at a specific time in the future: 'will be playing'.

questions.question: Fill in the blank with Future Perfect tense: I ___ (finish) my project by next week.
questions.explanation: Future Perfect tense is used for actions that will be completed by a certain future time: 'will have finished'.

questions.question: Which sentence is in Future Perfect Continuous tense?
options: She will study for three hours.
She will have been studying for three hours by 6 PM.
She will be studying at 6 PM.
questions.explanation: Future Perfect Continuous tense is formed with 'will have been + verb-ing', indicating an action ongoing up to a future time.

questions.question: Identify the tense in the sentence: 'I am reading a book.'
questions.explanation: The sentence uses 'am reading', which is Present Continuous tense.

questions.question: Change the sentence to Simple Past tense: 'She writes a letter.'
questions.explanation: Simple Past tense of 'writes' is 'wrote'.

questions.question: Correct the sentence: 'I am go to school.'
options: Both A and B are correct.
questions.explanation: Both 'I go to school' (Simple Present) and 'I am going to school' (Present Continuous) are grammatically correct, depending on the context.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'They ___ (finish) their homework before dinner.'
questions.explanation: Past Perfect tense is used because the action was completed before another past action (dinner).

questions.question: Which tense is used for general truths?
questions.explanation: Simple Present tense is used for general truths, like 'The sun rises in the east.'

questions.question: Choose the correct form: 'She ___ (sing) beautifully.'
questions.explanation: The sentence describes a general ability, so Simple Present tense is used: 'sings'.

questions.question: Fill in the blank with Present Perfect tense: 'I ___ (see) that movie.'
questions.explanation: Present Perfect tense is used for actions completed at an unspecified time: 'have seen'.

questions.question: Change to Past Continuous tense: 'He reads a book.'
questions.explanation: Past Continuous tense is 'was/were + verb-ing': 'He was reading a book.'

questions.question: Identify the error: 'They has finished their work.'
questions.explanation: For plural subjects like 'they', the correct auxiliary is 'have', not 'has'.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'By next year, I ___ (learn) French.'
questions.explanation: Future Perfect tense is used for actions that will be completed by a future time: 'will have learned'.

questions.question: Which sentence is in Simple Future tense?
questions.explanation: Simple Future tense uses 'will + base verb': 'I will go to school.'

questions.question: Choose the correct tense: 'She ___ (cook) dinner when the guests arrived.'
questions.explanation: Past Continuous tense is used for an ongoing action interrupted by another action: 'was cooking'.

questions.question: Fill in the blank with Future Continuous tense: 'At 8 PM, I ___ (watch) TV.'
questions.explanation: Future Continuous tense is used for actions that will be ongoing at a specific future time: 'will be watching'.

questions.question: Change to Present Perfect Continuous tense: 'She studies for two hours.'
options: She has studied for two hours.
She has been studying for two hours.
She is studying for two hours.
questions.explanation: Present Perfect Continuous tense emphasizes the duration of an action that started in the past and continues: 'has been studying'.

questions.question: Identify the tense: 'They had been playing before the rain started.'
questions.explanation: The sentence uses 'had been + verb-ing', which is Past Perfect Continuous tense.

questions.question: Correct the sentence: 'I will has finished my work by tomorrow.'
options: I will have finished my work by tomorrow.
I will finished my work by tomorrow.
I will be finish my work by tomorrow.
questions.explanation: Future Perfect tense requires 'will have + past participle': 'will have finished'.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'She ___ (not, eat) breakfast yet.'
questions.explanation: Present Perfect tense is used for actions not completed yet: 'has not eaten'.

questions.question: Which tense is used for actions that will be completed before another future action?
questions.explanation: Future Perfect tense is used for actions completed before a specific future time or action.

questions.question: Choose the correct form: 'By the time you arrive, I ___ (finish) cooking.'
questions.explanation: Future Perfect tense is used because the action will be completed before another future action: 'will have finished'.

questions.question: Fill in the blank with Past Perfect Continuous tense: 'They ___ (wait) for an hour before the bus came.'
questions.explanation: Past Perfect Continuous tense is used for actions that were ongoing before another past action: 'had been waiting'.

questions.question: Change to Simple Present tense: 'She was singing.'
questions.explanation: Simple Present tense of 'was singing' is 'sings'.

questions.question: Identify the tense: 'I will have been living here for five years by next month.'
questions.explanation: The sentence uses 'will have been + verb-ing', which is Future Perfect Continuous tense.

questions.question: Correct the sentence: 'He is play football every day.'
options: He is playing football every day.
questions.explanation: For habits, Simple Present tense is used: 'He plays football every day.'

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'If it ___ (rain), I will stay home.'
questions.explanation: In conditional sentences, Simple Present tense is used in the 'if' clause: 'If it rains'.

questions.question: Which sentence is in Present Continuous tense?
questions.explanation: Present Continuous tense is formed with 'is/are + verb-ing': 'She is reading a book.'

questions.question: Change to Past Perfect tense: 'They finished their work.'
questions.explanation: Past Perfect tense is 'had + past participle': 'They had finished their work.'

questions.question: Fill in the blank with Future Perfect Continuous tense: 'By 2025, I ___ (work) here for ten years.'
questions.explanation: Future Perfect Continuous tense is used for actions that will continue up to a future point: 'will have been working'.

questions.question: Identify the error: 'She will be go to the party.'
questions.explanation: The correct form for Future Continuous tense is 'will be + verb-ing': 'She will be going to the party.'
